Award.AwardTitle: Emergent Technologies: New Opportunities to Advance Psychological Research and Science Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Social Psychology Network (SPN) has become one of the most international and heavily used online networks for research and teaching in the social sciences. Most of its web resources, however, were designed before the widespread adoption of smartphones, tablets, and other mobile computers, which are now the most common devices used to access the Internet. To address this problem, the proposed project will advance psychological research and education by redesigning SPN so that its pages, interactive features, databases, and partner sites work with mobile devices. In addition to advancing research and science education through mobile technology, this project will also build on SPN's 18-year record of "giving psychology away," informing social issues, and broadening the participation of underrepresented groups. For example, the creation of mobile-friendly web pages will facilitate usage of the SPN Mentorship Program, in which more than 600 volunteers with doctoral degrees offer free career assistance to students from underrepresented groups. It will also increase access to SPN partner sites such as the Stanford Prison Experiment (PrisonExp.org), the Jigsaw Classroom (Jigsaw.org), and UnderstandingPrejudice.org, each of which focuses on social issues such as protecting human rights, preventing school violence, and reducing prejudice.

By refactoring SPN with a "mobile first" design approach, this project will ensure that the Network is interoperable and responsive across a wide array of computing devices, thereby making SPN more accessible and better equipped to serve the field as new mobile technologies continue to claim the future of social networking. This work will be completed in phases, beginning with the recruitment of a mobile design specialist and a technical audit to review elements including SPN's social media usage, search engine optimization, web hosting, server configuration, and choice of programming tools. The redesign and conversion of SPN sites will then begin with relatively small sites such as PrisonExp.org and eInterview.org before developing a new mobile design and programming for SocialPsychology.org. Next will come a redesign of SPN's system of 10,000+ user profiles and member pages, followed by a conversion of other SPN pages and features. In the end, this project will leave the Network well positioned to harness the power of the mobile revolution to advance psychological research and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Worldwide, the mobile technology revolution has profoundly reshaped business, mass media, politics, entertainment, and many other domains, but for the most part, the field of social psychology has not taken advantage of the unique opportunities that mobile technology offers. The purpose of this three-year project was to advance social psychology research and education by converting the largest online infrastructure in the field, Social Psychology Network (SPN), to be accessible on mobile devices such as smartphones and tablet computers, to add new mobile features and resources, and to expand SPN's use of social media.

Thanks to NSF funding, SPN successfully converted a majority of its websites to a responsive mobile-friendly design (Randomizer.org, Jigsaw.org, PrisonExp.org, and eInterview.org) and developed a new SPN partner site (ActionTeaching.org)—five mobile-friendly websites in all. In addition, the SPN team updated and enhanced many elements of SocialPsychology.org with an eye toward converting it to a mobile design in the future.

As just one example of this work, SPN radically redesigned its eInterview.org website, which simulates human-like interviews on complex topics. After extensive field-testing that took nearly a year to complete, the site now uses a text message format to give the impression that an interviewer is listening and responding to what the interviewee says. For instance, before the interviewer "sends" a lengthy question, the system displays animated responses to make it seem as though the interviewer is typing. To the best of my knowledge, this is the first time that an online system has used a text messaging interface to conduct human-like interviews capable of asking customized questions in more than a billion unique interview paths.

During the grant period, SPN also significantly expanded its social media content and subscriber base, thereby allowing members to communicate with each other and the general public with unprecedented reach and efficiency, and helping SPN disseminate research findings and other items of interest to a large global readership. As a result of this effort, SPN's Twitter streams are now followed by more than 260,000 people, and its Facebook page has approximately 270,000 "likes." Some tangible benefits of this effort are that items posted in SPN's Listserv Message Center instantly reach over 182,000 Twitter and RSS subscribers, and online study links reach over 236,000 subscribers—free services that allow users to collect online data and distribute information to a diverse international audience in a matter of minutes.

These changes have dramatically increased Network usage. Here, for example, are a few statistics that describe the current scope and reach of Social Psychology Network:

  • SPN's websites have now received more than 356 million webpage views.
  • SPN's now has a searchable database of more than 14,000 psychology and neuroscience news stories that have been visited over 16 million times.
  • SPN has posted free links to nearly 2,500 online studies and generated more than 1.3 million visits to these studies.
  • SPN now distributes nearly 24,000 free job alerts annually.
  • SPN has developed a geo-searchable database of 2,125 professional profiles, including 944 Media Contacts (willing to talk with reporters about topics of interest), and 652 SPN Mentors (willing to provide free career assistance to students from under-represented groups).
  • SPN's Research Randomizer tutorial on random sampling and random assignment has been completed more than 115,000 times, and its Randomizer form has been used to generate over 2.8 billion random numbers.
  • SPN's website on the Stanford Prison Experiment, which is devoted to prison reform and the protection of human rights, has received over 172 million page views.
  • SPN's Jigsaw Classroom web site, which applies social psychology research findings to reduce racial prejudice and school violence, has received more than 6 million page views.
  • SPN's Joe Chemo website, which uses web-based technologies to reduce underage smoking, has now received more than 5 million page views.

Finally, thanks to NSF funding over the past 20 years, SPN has been able to employ 91 people, 84 of whom have been student interns. Approximately 68% of these interns have been female and 48% have been students of color—a level of diversity that has greatly enriched the Network and its services.

In sum, NSF funding has been instrumental in enabling Social Psychology Network to incorporate the latest mobile technologies, building and serving SPN's global user base in ways that advance the field and serve the general public.
